column21: a supernumerary; while Mr Watt the boatswain and five seamen were severely wounded. To render just praise to the gallant conduct and impetuous attack of Mr Dillon
column22: I am perfectly unequal to."|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: 03:00|"three in the morning"|"In fact
column2: their treatment was even shabbier than rumour had it. The Sophie's commander and her surgeon sat in the cabin amidst a heap of papers
column3: for Stephen Maturin had been helping with some of the paper work as well as writing returns and letters of his own
column4: and now it was three in the morning: the Sophie rocked gently at her moorings
column5: and her tight-packed crew were snorting the long night through (the rare joys of harbour-watch). Jack had not gone ashore at all - had no intention of going ashore; and now the silence
column6: the lack of real motion
column7: the long sitting with pen and ink seemed to insulate them from the world in their illuminated cell; and this made their conversation
column8: which would have been indecent at almost any other time
column9: seem quite ordinary and natural. 'Do you know that fellow Martinez?' asked Jack quietly. 'The man whose house the Hartes have part of?'"|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: ~ 00:00|"about midnight"|"'Mr Day
column2: ' said Jack
column3: 'be so good as to prepare some fire barrels - say half a dozen. Mr Daiziel
column4: unless it comes on to blow I think we may take the boats in at about midnight. Dr Maturin
column5: let us rejoice and be gay.'"|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: ap 10:14|"Fourteen minutes past ten"|"Jack looked up at the sky. It looked down on him
column2: a broad and meaningless expanse
column3: with stray clouds passing over it - the wind would not die away that afternoon: night was still hours and hours away. How many? He glanced at his watch. Fourteen minutes past ten. 'Mr Daiziel
column4: ' he said
column5: 'I am going into my cabin. Call me if anything whatever occurs. Mr Richards
column6: be so good as to tell Dr Maturin I should like to speak to him. And Mr Watt
column7: let me have a couple of fathoms of logline and three or four belaying-pins.'"|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: ap 01:00|one|"'I did
column2: sir
column3: ' said Captain Ferris. 'I struck my colours
column4: ' he said in a wondering tone and at once began to sob
column5: staring open-eyed at them - at one and then at the other."|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: < 12:00|"before noon"|"a yard across. She got it in so quickly that the top was over before noon
column2: and neither it nor the deck could be seen for the number of men working on the rigging."|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: 12:00|noon|"During the night a hint of a Levanter began to breathe from the east: this was the wind the Spaniards were praying for
column2: the wind that would carry them straight out of the Gut
column3: once they had weathered Cabrita Point
column4: and waft them up to Cadiz. At noon the first of their three-deckers loosed her foretopsail and began to move out of the crowded road; then the others followed her. They were weighing and coming out at intervals of ten minutes or a quarter of an hour to their rendezvous off Cabrita Point. The Caesar was still tied up alongside the mole
column5: taking in her powder and shot
column6: with officers
column7: men
column8: civilians and garrison soldiers working with silent concentrated earnestness."|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: ap 07:30|"half-past seven"|"Not a word
column2: not a sign: a silent sea
column3: a silent sky and the wind grown treacherous again - all round the compass. At half-past seven Jack saw Stephen back to the hospital
column4: revived himself with coffee and climbed again."|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: < 00:00|"just before midnight"|"'I don't know all the details
column2: ' said Jack
column3: 'but this is the gist of it. That noble fellow Keats - you remember how we saw him shoot ahead? - came up with their rear
column4: the two Spanish first-rates
column5: just before midnight. He chose his moment
column6: clapped his helm a lee and dashed between 'em firing both broadsides - a seventy-four taking on two first-rates! He shot straight on
column7: leaving his smoke-cloud between 'em as thick as peasoup; and each
column8: firing into it
column9: hit the other; and so the Real Carlos and the Hermenegildo went for each other like fury in the dark. Someone
column11: had knocked away the Real Carlos' foretopmast
column12: and it was her topsail that fell over the guns and took fire. And after a while the Real Carios fell"|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: ~ 06:00|"About six o'clock in the morning"|"Jack rose to his feet
column2: looked sharply along the line of his judges
column3: drew his breath
column4: and speaking in a much stronger voice than usual
column5: the words coming fast
column6: with odd intervals and an unnatural intonation - a harsh
column7: God-damn-you voice
column8: as though he were addressing a most inimical body of men - he said
column9: 'About six o'clock in the morning of the third
column10: to the eastward and in sight of Cape Roig
column11: we saw three large ships apparently French

column1: ap ~ 09:00|"about nine o'clock"|"soon after gave chase to the Sophie: the Sophie was between the shore and the ships that chased her
column2: and to windward of the French vessels: we endeavoured by making all sail and were pulling with sweeps - as the wind was very light to keep to windward of the enemy; but having found notwithstanding all our endeavours to keep to the wind
column3: that the French ships gained very fast
column4: and having separated on different tacks one or the other gained upon each shift of wind
column5: and finding it impracticable to escape by the wind
column6: about nine o'clock the guns and other things on deck were thrown overboard; and having watched an opportunity
column7: when the nearest French ship was on our quarter
column8: we bore up and set the studdingsails; but again found the French ships outsailed us though their studdingsails were not set:"|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: ~ 11:00|"about eleven o'clock a.m."|"when the nearest ship had approached within musket-shot
column2: -I ordered the colours to be hauled down about eleven o'clock a.m.
column3: the wind being to the eastward and having received several broadsides from the enemy which carried away the maintopgallantmast and foretopsail yard and cut several of the ropes.' -"|"Master and Commander"|"Patrick O'Brian"
